comments.commentBody:
Actually, here is a better link, as it is more recent and relevant to our current economic situation.

It discusses the distinction between the low inflation economy we have and outright deflation, and posits a hypothesis as to the "stickiness" of low but positive inflation in the presence of a weak economy due to nominal wage rigidity.

It also happens to be the first in a long series on the topic from the same Keynsian on whose blog you posted accusing Keynesians of conflating deflation and low inflation. Ironic right?

http://krugman.blogs.nytimes.com/2013/03/05/why-dont-we-have-deflation/
Abysssinia!

Anyone notice from left to right, the alcoholic content of RYE, HIC and OENO midway across ACME's grid?

TUVALU, ICU!

Karen,

Your comment is spot on. I can't understand why the Feds Triennial Survey of Households has not been the flag of those who want a fair government. Anyhow here is the link, http://www.federalreserve.gov/pubs/bulletin/2014/pdf/scf14.pdf

I have been watching the underemployed rate, people who can't find full time work, or they are working for much less income than they would make if the economy was normal.

I also don't understand why we make huge infrastructure decisions like high speed rail (that must be subsidized) and ignore our own 300 mph Maglev system, which only has to be tested and certified as a public carrier. It carries trucks, as well as passengers and the fares are much, much less. 5 cents a passenger mile versus $1 per passenger mile for Amtrak. Amazingly, Japan has developed a superconducting Maglev train that uses the invention of the two American's who invented it, Drs. James Powell and Gordon Danby, and they propose to demonstrate the system in the US between Baltimore and Washington, DC. Their first investment was in a very powerful lobbying team. Japan Maglev is the passenger only 1st gen system. Powell and Danby have kept working and now have a system which lifts trucks, electronically switches and can be build along the Interstates with private investment and not require subsidies to construct or operate. see: www.magneticglide.com

It can make you a little crazy.

Speaking as a 'Nam vet, I would say you're spot on, Steve. I went in with a fierce determination to stop those dreaded Communists from taking over Southeast Asia (and then the globe), quickly learning the folly--the bottomless folly--of the venture.

As a war-making nation, we've mastered the craft of putting lipstick on a pig. Drones are only the newest shade from Revlon.

Yes, I was there also, at a base three miles south of Hue. It was one of the most unnecessary wars in history, which is saying something.

I started talking to this guy in a barbershop the other day. Guess when he was in Vietnam? 1954. Yeah, we helped the French try to recolonize (if that's the word) Vietnam after World War II. How stupid was that? Truman started it right off the bat from WW II.

If Roosevelt had lived there would have no Vietnam war. In my opinion Truman betrayed everybody. (Excuse me for the digression. Thanks for the comment, Moss.)

Sometimes people fight in wars that matter so much to their country or group that they are willing to die in the cause. I'm thinking of the Vietnamese in their long struggle against colonialism, the same for the Koreans, North and South actually. And the Russians come to mind with their epic struggle for survival as a nation in World War II.

And World War II was the last time Americans fought in a war of that kind. Since then in Korea, Vietnam, Iraq, Afganistan--those wars are not being fought for the survival of the United States or any freedoms therein. In other words motivation on our part is lacking. No one wants to die, but it's especially galling to die when the reason for your death in battle is essentially no reason that matters to you.

That's why our rulers use bombs and drones and don't put any boots on the ground (if they can help it). It does most definitely have a cowardly aspect.

Leapfinger...

Backer slew!

Danke, Martin, for going to the trouble to explain the diff. betw. DRECK and Schlock for yours truly, I most sincerely appreciate it.

Howie

Point taken, however economics sometimes seems more like a smokescreen for ideology than a science or social science. I see economists interviewed on TV all the time and they're almost never talking theory and metrics, or analyzing policies, and they're almost always advocating in dire tones for whatever silver bullet policy fantasy is outlined on that week's party talking points. If it's supposed to sound like educated analysis then it's a complete fail. It's indistinguishable from propaganda; it's indecipherable from propaganda.

Meanwhile, tele-head economists use the word "growth" more often than your average Buddhist monk makes the sound, "ohm." And every time it hear it, I cringe. Maybe because "growth" seems so mindless? Growth is what happens to the voracious eater to make him morbidly obese. Growth is a byword for a cancerous tumor.
How can infinite growth be possible in a finite world? Won't it just lead to resource exhaustion and bleak cannibalism?

Jared Diamond asks what the Easter Islander who cut down the very last tree on the island must have thought as he was doing the cutting. I would contend that he was an economist excited that the Easter Island economy had exceeded its "growth" projections that year.

There are typing and signing non-human apes, and birds with not only speech but grammar and meaningful language use. When any of them advocate for some form of rights, I will listen.

Until then, I will continue my distrust of organizations who claim to speak for a group without having members from that group. If the entire large category does not bother to protest for their rights, they clearly don't want them very much.

Our species has several unique traits: We've developed language, we have developed the concept of rights, and sending people to the moon is about as apart from nature as you can get. One can understand that humans deserve more rights than beasts who could never do these things without subscribing to any religion.
In no economic theory or teaching is maximizing in illegal or immoral ways advanced. You are blaming economics for human failings.  It is not the science, it is the nature of man, you included.
The only problem is, other economic systems are even worse.

Capitalism is a greed based system. By its own rationality it is right to maximize profits in anyway possible. Lying, cheating, shutting out your employees, using them as puppets, or outsourcing your company, failing to invest in the future, all these and more are fair ways to aggrandize your shareholders and CEO's. Rationality depends upon the underlying system you use to create that rationality. If you base everything on short term greed as our corporations do then you create the oligarchic system that globally and in particular our country we have become.

This is not new . it is as old as dictatorship and our tendency to feed on others. The main difference is that corporations can exert their greedy capitalism globally and governments that might control them have lost the will to do so or more likely have been bought by these corporations.

The science of economics gets a lot right. At any point in time, there are concerns in any science. That is why we keep testing. In addition, the pretenders at science will carry on like proponents of creation science for political gain and the petting of egos.

Science by definition is an evolving endeavor, an art. The crackpots and frauds will attack it for that to because they want the rewards without the price of long practice.

The economics of the super super-rich and many that pretend to be are focused on the prosperity engines of only their wealth. Their continuing education and their politics are in the building of their estates. The laws and institutions they perpetuate care little for individuals in lower class.

The economics of those individuals are far different. They are, we are like peasants, locking ourselves out of prosperity promised for most of the 20th century.

We need to be boycotting their stores and products. Turn off their entertainment apparatus that pacifies the masses better than any opiate. Stop buying there junk, and listening to their lies. We can make a difference. Get to the polls. We have the power to make a difference in our economics now.

Voting by mail is underway here in North Carolina. Exercise your right to take the power back from the business interests that are outsourcing our future. Don’t have a ballot yet? Contact your county board of election. They will help. Spread the word, in NC, you don’t need a voter ID to vote in 2014.

That's what we need: more capitalism in education and healthcare.  Why don't we also throw in the military and the police.  We already see private companies making millions off war and prisons.  The more they make, the more they can lobby for more war and prisons.  We could have corporations running all the schools (not just a few) and they could "run them like a business, and investors could make more and more money on them.  The government shouldn't regulate health insurance either.  Let the insurance companies run it.  That has always worked out well unless you got sick or got old or were poor.  Medicare came about because older Americans could not get coverage because unregulated private insurance companies do not want to insure anyone that might have a claim.  Medicaid came about because unregulated capitalists don't want to pay American workers a living wage that allows them to get healthcare.  As for Estonia, the forecasts I can find indicate GDP growth for 2014 will be .5% to 2%.  I'm not sure I'd call that great.  I'm not sure that Estonia proves your point that more capitalism is good since they have very generous social insurance system including pensions, generous family allowances, health insurance, unemployment insurance, benefits for disabled persons, benefits for repressed persons, and funeral benefits. I think that Paul Ryan would find them more "socialist" than we are.

I'll believe that economics as a field has faced reality when it stops assuming that an economy is healthy only when it is growing.  Exponential curves, decade in and decade out, in the face of finite resources and finite markets, seem the definition of unreality.

For some strange reason, the wheelers and dealers of the U.S. economy remain blissfully ignorant that approximately 70% of the U.S. Gross Domestic Product is based upon the purchase of goods and services with the middle class representing the bulk of that activity (low income families can barely get by and high income earners tend to sit on their income and assets).

The monied class also congratulated themselves on their very success stripping of income and assets from the working class, middle class, and retiree pot that resulted in a reduced portion of the nation’s wealth and flat earned income after adjusting for inflation for the past thirty years. The wheelers and dealers never connected the dots that continuing take more and more money out of the pot resulted in a drop in earnings after inflation that was accompanied with large increases in education and health care costs.

In short, the top tenth of one percent are eating the golden goose and the golden eggs of the U.S. economy while they slowly, but inexorably, push the United States to third-world status in their continued destruction of the consumer goods and services portion of the U.S. economy.

Shouldn't the issue of accountability for the 2008 crash also play a role in all this retrospection? Setting aside the fevered myth of the "Barney Frank made banks give mortgages to black people" meme, I've seen plenty of evidence not only of rampant illegality in the financial sector leading up to the crash, but also after the crash of the Obama admin. coddling the offenders with meaningless fines while giving them all a Get Out of Jail Free card.

Recently while scouting out prospects for employment in Australia, someone told me that it had largely weathered the 2008 crisis. It suddenly struck me how widespread and destructive the crisis was/is, the image of Australia as a remote island that had survived a worldwide tsunami. Don't just focus on the U.S.: the Crash of 2008 rivals the Great Depression and World War II in terms of its worldwide destructive impact. There were trials after the Great Depression of some of the malefactors involved. There were the Nuremberg trials after WW II. Where is the accountability for this catastrophe?

Patrice, great comment - we have a democratic deficit due to voter apathy. I argue that the only thing wrong is people are too complacent. Science always gets it wrong, but it is a self correcting method. We need to think like that about our political course. It has happened here before. We can make a difference.

It's not just economics going wrong, it's society gone wrong, politics stuck on ever higher plutocracy,

What you say is that, starting after the election of Ronald Reagan, influential academics in economy were into just one model, that greed is not just good, but everything. They were into what one ought to call intellectual fascism. This has happened in other fields: in physics, say at Princeton, it became impossible to get a job if one was not a string theorist. Never mind one had never seen a string, nor could one ever see one.

The fault that lie in ourselves is to have let a non-democratic political system grow and control us. It found economists to say what they wanted to hear. The solution? Direct democracy. Swiss "votations" changed fundamentally the way the Swiss banking system works. They also changed the way the wealthy can influence society. A "votation" even proposed to limit the salary multiplier in companies to only ten (whereas in the USA , the average CEO of large companies earn 400 times what the more modest employees make... the gap was only 50 a few decades ago). That particular referendum failed. Yet California, after a similar vote, decided to tax the rich more. And it worked; California does not have a deficit problem anymore.

So what we fundamentally have is a deficit problem. A democratic deficit problem, and it impacts the way the economy, and society, are directed. This has happened to civilization before, when oligarchy turns to plutocracy.

Equal numbers employing equivalent means is essential to fair play. That's why it's usually confined to sport. Nowhere in the history of warfare has anyone who thought their survival depend on defeating the enemy been concerned with technological or numerical equality. For example, there is evidence that some military leaders in Japan thought that American technological advantages could be overcome by the bravery of their soldiers, sailors and airmen. There is ample evidence to suggest they were wrong.

A timely piece indeed, and a welcome reminder that the "conduct of war" matters (although perhaps not as much as the "outcome of war"). The main thesis advanced by the author seems to be that unless we all have "skin in the game" we will not appreciate the sacrifices, yea, the horrors of war. (Oddly, this associate professor at the Maryland Institute College of Art seems to claim a full appreciation of the sacrifices and horrors; I figured the author must be a decorated war hero.) Anyway, the citizen-soldier is an outmoded, fruitless, and tyrannical ideal. Any general can tell you that the self-selected, all-volunteer army performs better where performance matters. The goal IS to insulate the populace from costs (other than the trillions we taxpayers have spent); our modern military is costly but efficient at their job. To those Americans who believe in liberty (as few dictates from the government as possible), the military draft must be anathema. The idea of compulsory national service, of taking a young person's best years and forcing them to give it in service, whether military or otherwise, is often counterproductive.

You said exactly what I planned to say as I began to read this article. The attitude that war is hell and anything goes for the more technologically advanced can come back to haunt us as more countries advance their drones and other remote controlled war machines. If/when this happens we cannot deny others their own perverted war doctrines, including preemptive strikes based on a whim.

Is this the legacy we want to leave our future generations? This of course implies that a future exists. Someone may come up with their own crazy doctrine of preemptive drone delivered nuclear war heads. They will probably use the same line use by some here.

Please point me to a time in history when we as a nation decided to sacrifice the lives of American soldiers when we had the technological means to achieve a necessary military objective without doing so. The closest I can come was to the reluctance of the Pentagon to adopt automatic rifles, and that delay is best described as stupid.

Also it is wrong to imply that terrorism is merely something that we decide to call terrorism. Terrorism is not defined by the means, it is defined by the target. A drone launch against a military installation in a war is not terrorism; a drone launch against a room full of schoolchildren is.

I honestly don't understand how people can fail to understand such a simple word, or concept.

The main point I tried to make was concerning setting precedence, and whether we would accept other countries to practice what we currently do in sovereign air space belonging to other countries.

But this is interesting:

"A drone launch against a military installation in a war is not terrorism; a drone launch against a room full of schoolchildren is."

You've answered your own question. This happens regularly in Yemen, Afghanistan, and Pakistan to school children and people in weddings. They are not war targets. But they are taken out, which makes our action terrorism.

If Machiavelli was right, if military conduct is indeed a reflection of a nation's character, then drone warfare may well be the quintessential expression of contemporary American character:  a nation of couch potatoes playing "video games" where real flesh and blood human beings are the targets  but who are too insensitive and clueless to comprehend the inevitable consequences of their actions.  Sooner or later, others will have drone technology capable of inflicting harm upon the United States, and when that happens the couch potatoes will call it "terrorism" and moan "why do they hate us?"

@ Kip:

I agree with you that personal attacks are inappropriate. Roddy's latest was a drive-by shooting with a BB gun by comparison to his "satire" against Watts highlighted by another commenter, however.

This exposes not only his lack of class - it is an expression of his frustration that there are regular readers of the NYT who do not share his view. This is probably because he lacks a coherent counter-argument to calm factual reasoning.

Thank you for your level-headed contributions to Dot Earth and for your efforts to keep it civil.

Kurt in Switzerland

When things are going "up up up", though -- most people are happy (except for first time buyers) and thrilled with their profits and equity.

At the height of the bubble, had you sold your $88K home, you would have gotten something like $160,000 profit on it, in only 10 years.

Today, I wonder what your home is worth. The crash dropped prices down back to 1998 levels, but since 2013, prices in Florida are dramatically increased. I see new construction all over again. I also see that investors have grabbed every distressed property -- for cash -- and it is impossible for ordinary buyers to compete for these homes. They rehab quickly and cheaply, often as soon as 3 weeks after purchase, then put the homes back on the market for double and triple the purchase price!

In short: things are almost back to the peak of the market in 2006 -- OK, not quite but maybe at 2004 levels. It won't be long before the next crash.

I bought my 1500 square foot house for 88K in 1998. Going towards 2008, similar houses like mine in the same neighborhood were selling for 250K. I had remarked to some builders and ex-builders that such value was unsustainable, for the simple reason that I would not have been able to buy the same house in 2008 as our household income would not have caught up with that rate of increase. It was a simple start up home meant for first time home buyer. At that rate, my kids would not be able to afford their first home. My builder and ex-builder acquaintances just shrugged their shoulder and said that's how real estate worked and nothing was amiss. I felt differently. As it turned out, my observation was correct despite my lack of knowledge in economic or business. I simply observed and reflected, honestly.

We have a problem of having very intelligent but very dishonest people running our government and society; and worst, also motivated by selfish self interests.

I was planning to post a comment about Don Quixote losing his mind from reading medieval romances, but I'm pleased you already did! I didn't even think about poor Paolo and Francesca, but that's right on target too!

The dangers of reading novels was not just a feminist issue. In the 16th century, if I am not mistaken, Cervantes' Don Quixote was inspired by romances to embark on his improbable quests. It was not a woman, in this early example of the dangers of reading, who was unable to distinguish reality.

There was also Paolo and Francesca in Dante's Inferno whose reading about Lancelot and Guinevere had disastrous consequences.

The macroeconomic basics for dealing with the recession I learned back in the 1960's in Paul Samuelson's Eonomics text.  Theory based on Keynes.  They made sense then and they make sense now.  The deep economic damage, probably permanent for a large number of people, was brought about by leaders who stubbornly follow ideology rather than being informed about reality.

Bob, you're missing the very essence of terrorism -- attacks directed at innocent civilians.

You've also drawn a false analogy because you don't understand the difference between American drone attacks and your hypothetical drone attacks on the terrorists in the United States. In general, when we use drones in countries like Pakistan, it is with the permission of the nation involved, and it is in an essentially lawless situation. Otherwise, that nation's police or military could deal with the terrorists.

There are also cases in which it is legal under international law and morally justifiable to attack without a nation's permission. Our original attack on Bin Laden in Afghanistan would be an example of that. Then the applicable laws and moral framework are those of war. As tings now stand, few nations have a legal right to make war against the United States, or to send drones across our border without our permission. Those few that do would quickly regret it.

Other nations do have the right to use Mexico or Honduras for drone bases, assuming they have the permission of the Mexican or Honduran governments.
You could have used "carpet-bombing" instead of "drones in your argument.  Would you like to go back to carpet-bombing?  Ask the few survivors of WWII's intentional firestorm bombing.

Drones are an example of our self-blindness, which is an important element of our Exceptionalism. For example, why aren't drones considered weapons of terror? Look at the parallels between the use of hijacked planes on 9/11 and our now routine use of drones. The main difference is that by definition nothing we do is considered terrorism, whether with drones, torture, or kicking in doors of peasants at midnight. Or widespread use of contractors who are outside all law of accountability, just possible recall by their employers.

And have we legitimized the use of drones? For example, if the Chinese unilaterally decided to use drones to kill alleged Uighur or Tibetan terrorists in the United States, would it be reasonable for them to carry out such strikes in the United States -- limited only by the practical matter of avoiding being shot out of the sky? Would it be accepted that sometimes they'd make a mistake and blow up a wedding party? Would it be OK for them to negotiate with Mexico or Honduras to site drone bases?

The IBM I joined in 1966 had similar policies, and I was able to retire with a defined benefits pension when my unit was sold to the now defunct original AT&T in 1999. I also remember that hourly workers were only 'hourly' in the sense that thay got paid overtime, but like 'exempt' workers got paid anyway if absent for sickness or family crisis, it was basically up to the individual's supervisor to decide whether the reported reason for absence was valid. I had a 401(k) offered in the early '80s on top of my guaranteed pension, 3 weeks vacation after 5 years, 4 after 10, and 5 after 20. So, I had 5 weeks vacation for 13 years, just what my French in-laws got at the start.

LOL -- the wealth of San Francisco does not come from deficit spending, David! are you kidding me?

It comes from two major industries: banking and tech, which are booming like the old Gold Rush days. The banks because nobody ever re-regulated them via Glass Steagall. The tech companies, because they are almost the only strong, profitable industry we have left. It is all centered near San Francisco.

Of course the cost for this is that housing is utterly unaffordable. I assume you "got yours" decades ago, and don't have to worry. For everyone else, housing costs in SF are a nightmare.....the median home price is over $1 MILLION and that's for a tiny bungalow on a zero line lot.

BTW: companies like Google and Apple are the new "Hughes Aircraft" and they do provide employees with insanely luxurious pay, benefits and freebies.

The 1950s? The 1960s? No competition from overseas. Russia and China were communist, India was socialist, Europe was still struggling to regain and rebuild. We had all the wealth, and could afford anything.

Not so today.

Thoughts on deficit spending.
We spent the afternoon attending the SF Opera performance of Norma by Bellini.

Standing on the balcony of the opera house during intermission I could see several construction cranes. The city is as busy as I have ever seen it. The War Memorial Opera House and the Veterans Memorial building next to it were built in the middle of the great depression, as was the Golden Gate Bridge we drove across to get there, all on credit.

Standing there I recalled that I had once worked for America's wealthiest man, Howard Hughes. Howard would walk through his factories, he knew the assembly line employees, the janitors, the engineers. Hughes Aircraft had a defined pension plan, a 401K when it became available, good wages, a generous vacation schedule, including the time from Christmas to New Years, at company expense.
Donald Douglas of Douglas Aircraft also treated his employees as well.

I can not think of current CEO that treats the employees like Douglas and Hughes did. It is the stockholders that come first. The cheaper the labor, the more the returns on equity. This recession would go away in a year, if companies would give a living wage, and benefits.

These programs compound, they increase they give one group discretionary income, which is spent increasing the income of the next group.
Deficit spending gave SF a lasting legacy, it is that most liberal of cities that is thriving. Think about that.
Fanny and Freddy currently own or guarantee 90% of all mortgage contracts. Facts are stubborn things.

No matter how you spin it, most of the loans that defaulted would have never ever been made in the first place, if it were not for FHA, Fannie, Freddie guarantees.

Homeowners with no money down, bad credit scores took advantage of them. Banks took advantage of them. Investment bankers took advantage of them.

But it all started with the loans being made with abandon, because of government involvement.

Go and try to get a non-conforming, non-government entity guaranteed loan for a bank, with no collateral, bad credit score, no income documentation. You will be instantly laughed out of the bank.

With Uncle Sam not only guaranteeing the loans, but also threatening to sue you if you made it harder for inner-city, poor or black individuals to get them (regardless of their financial abilities), the flood gates were open.

Very true, Baron95. The deniers should look up two things: Bill Clinton's "National Homeownership Strategy" and GW Bush's "Ownership Society", which was a rebranding of the Clinton program.

But that's not the end of the story. By 2007-8, with all those toxic assets based on fraudulent mortgages on the books, there was still a way to correct the problem: loan restructuring. This would equalize the loss in value seen by both lenders and borrowers, rather than have borrowers suffer all the loss, with lenders protected from loss. The justifications for this radical solution would have been (1) the lenders' toxic assets' values were fraudulent, and (2) protecting the toxic assets' values was not possible anyway without other extreme measures, such as bailing out banks and QE by the Fed. The benefits of this solution would have been a lower private debt load, which would have allowed higher consumer spending, which would have kept the economy growing. And we wouldn't still have toxic assets on the books six years after a crash that never should have happened.

There was only one big failure in economic policy that disproportionately contributed to the crisis.

And Dr. Krugman never ever raised it, before, during or after the crisis.

The US is the only country in the world where 2 government sponsored organizations and a government agency control the financing for over 90% of the residential real estate market. And those organizations, under pressure from Democrats like Barney Frank, were pushing all sorts of loans to barely qualified individuals.

That is the failure - 3 government participants - controlling the market with implicit guarantees. That is the source of the distortion.

Market participants kept the party going until enough folks started to question it, buying swaps, shorting bonds - i.e. predicting the end of the party - that the music stopped.

As painful as it may be, the re-set is actually quite healthy, and further government intervention, beyond stabilizing the banks, is probably more distortive than helpful.
